column3: 1)	" Good evening. It's great to be here in Atlanta for this debate where America will be showcased to the world when the 1996 Olympics are put on right here. It's appropriate because in a real sense
column4: our discussion this evening will be about what kind of nation we want to be 4 years from now. It's also a pleasure to be with my 2 opponents this evening. Admiral Stockdale
column5: may I say it's a special honor to share this stage with you. Those of us who served in Vietnam looked at you as a national hero even before you were awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor. And Mr. Vice President -- Dan
column6: if I may -- it was 16 years ago that you and I went to the Congress on the very first day together. I'll make you a deal this evening. If you don't try to compare George Bush to Harry Truman
column7: I won't compare you to Jack Kennedy.  (APPLAUSE)  Harry Truman --

column1: Do you remember the last time someone compared themselves to Jack Kennedy? Do you remember what they said?

column3: assumed the presidency when Franklin Roosevelt died here in Georgia -- only one of many occasions when fate thrust a vice president into the Oval Office in a time of crisis. It's something to think about during the debate this evening. But our real discussion is going to be about change. Bill Clinton and I stand for change because we don't believe our nation can stand 4 more years of what we've had under George Bush and Dan Quayle. When the recession came they were like a deer caught in the headlights -- paralyzed into inaction
column4: blinded to the suffering and pain of bankruptcies and people who were unemployed. We have an environmental crisis
column5: a health insurance crisis
column6: substandard education. It is time for a change.  Bill Clinton and I want to get our country moving forward again
column7: put our people back to work
column8: and create a bright future for the US of America.

column3: Senator Gore
column4: for reminding me about my performance in the 1988 vice presidential debate. This is 1992
column5: Bill Clinton is running against President George Bush. There are 2 things that I'm going to stress during this debate: one
column6: Bill Clinton's economic plan and his agenda will make matters much
column7: much worse -- he will raise your taxes
column8: he will increase spending
column9: he will make government bigger
column10: jobs will be lost; second
column11: Bill Clinton does not have the strength nor the character to be president of the US. (APPLAUSE)  Let us look at the agendas. President Bush wants to hold the line on taxes
column12: Bill Clinton wants to raise taxes. President Bush is for a balanced budget amendment
column13: Bill Clinton is opposed to it. We want to reform the legal system because it's too costly
column14: Bill Clinton wants the status quo. We want to reform the health care system
column15: Bill Clinton wants to ration health care. Bill Clinton wants to empower government
column16: we want to empower people.  In St. Louis
column17: Missouri
column19: Bill Clinton said this: ""America is the mockery of the world."" He is wrong.  At some time during these next 4 years there is going to be a crisis -- there will be an international crisis. I can't tell you where it's going to be
column20: I can't even tell you the circumstances -- but it will happen. We need a president who has the experience
column21: who has been tested
column22: who has the integrity and qualifications to handle the crisis. The president has been tested
column23: the president has the integrity and the character. The choice is yours.  You need to have a president you can trust. Can you really trust Bill Clinton?

column1: Who am I? Why am I here? (Laughter and applause)  I'm not a politician -- everybody knows that. So don't expect me to use the language of the Washington insider. Thirty-seven years in the Navy
column2: and only one of them up there in Washington. And now I'm an academic.  The centerpiece of my life was the Vietnam War. I was there the day it started. I led the first bombing raid against North Vietnam. I was there the day it ended
column3: and I was there for everything in between. Ten years in Vietnam
column4: aerial combat
column5: and torture. I know things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world. I know some things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world.  And I know how governments
column6: how American governments can be -- can be courageous
column7: and how they can be callow. And that's important. That's one thing I'm an insider on.  I was the leader of the underground of the American pilots who were shot down in prison in North Vietnam. You should know that the American character displayed in those dungeons by those fine men was a thing of beauty.  I look back on those years as the beginning of wisdom
column8: learning everything a man can learn about the vulnerabilities and the strengths that are ours as Americans.  Why am I here tonight? I am here because I have in my brain and in my heart what it takes to lead America through tough times.

column3: 1)	" Good evening. It's great to be here in Atlanta for this debate where America will be showcased to the world when the 1996 Olympics are put on right here. It's appropriate because in a real sense
column4: our discussion this evening will be about what kind of nation we want to be 4 years from now. It's also a pleasure to be with my 2 opponents this evening. Admiral Stockdale
column5: may I say it's a special honor to share this stage with you. Those of us who served in Vietnam looked at you as a national hero even before you were awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor. And Mr. Vice President -- Dan
column6: if I may -- it was 16 years ago that you and I went to the Congress on the very first day together. I'll make you a deal this evening. If you don't try to compare George Bush to Harry Truman
column7: I won't compare you to Jack Kennedy.  (APPLAUSE)  Harry Truman --

column1: Do you remember the last time someone compared themselves to Jack Kennedy? Do you remember what they said?

column3: assumed the presidency when Franklin Roosevelt died here in Georgia -- only one of many occasions when fate thrust a vice president into the Oval Office in a time of crisis. It's something to think about during the debate this evening. But our real discussion is going to be about change. Bill Clinton and I stand for change because we don't believe our nation can stand 4 more years of what we've had under George Bush and Dan Quayle. When the recession came they were like a deer caught in the headlights -- paralyzed into inaction
column4: blinded to the suffering and pain of bankruptcies and people who were unemployed. We have an environmental crisis
column5: a health insurance crisis
column6: substandard education. It is time for a change.  Bill Clinton and I want to get our country moving forward again
column7: put our people back to work
column8: and create a bright future for the US of America.

column3: Senator Gore
column4: for reminding me about my performance in the 1988 vice presidential debate. This is 1992
column5: Bill Clinton is running against President George Bush. There are 2 things that I'm going to stress during this debate: one
column6: Bill Clinton's economic plan and his agenda will make matters much
column7: much worse -- he will raise your taxes
column8: he will increase spending
column9: he will make government bigger
column10: jobs will be lost; second
column11: Bill Clinton does not have the strength nor the character to be president of the US. (APPLAUSE)  Let us look at the agendas. President Bush wants to hold the line on taxes
column12: Bill Clinton wants to raise taxes. President Bush is for a balanced budget amendment
column13: Bill Clinton is opposed to it. We want to reform the legal system because it's too costly
column14: Bill Clinton wants the status quo. We want to reform the health care system
column15: Bill Clinton wants to ration health care. Bill Clinton wants to empower government
column16: we want to empower people.  In St. Louis
column17: Missouri
column19: Bill Clinton said this: ""America is the mockery of the world."" He is wrong.  At some time during these next 4 years there is going to be a crisis -- there will be an international crisis. I can't tell you where it's going to be
column20: I can't even tell you the circumstances -- but it will happen. We need a president who has the experience
column21: who has been tested
column22: who has the integrity and qualifications to handle the crisis. The president has been tested
column23: the president has the integrity and the character. The choice is yours.  You need to have a president you can trust. Can you really trust Bill Clinton?

column1: Who am I? Why am I here? (Laughter and applause)  I'm not a politician -- everybody knows that. So don't expect me to use the language of the Washington insider. Thirty-seven years in the Navy
column2: and only one of them up there in Washington. And now I'm an academic.  The centerpiece of my life was the Vietnam War. I was there the day it started. I led the first bombing raid against North Vietnam. I was there the day it ended
column3: and I was there for everything in between. Ten years in Vietnam
column4: aerial combat
column5: and torture. I know things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world. I know some things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world.  And I know how governments
column6: how American governments can be -- can be courageous
column7: and how they can be callow. And that's important. That's one thing I'm an insider on.  I was the leader of the underground of the American pilots who were shot down in prison in North Vietnam. You should know that the American character displayed in those dungeons by those fine men was a thing of beauty.  I look back on those years as the beginning of wisdom
column8: learning everything a man can learn about the vulnerabilities and the strengths that are ours as Americans.  Why am I here tonight? I am here because I have in my brain and in my heart what it takes to lead America through tough times.

column1: Who am I? Why am I here? (Laughter and applause)  I'm not a politician -- everybody knows that. So don't expect me to use the language of the Washington insider. Thirty-seven years in the Navy
column2: and only one of them up there in Washington. And now I'm an academic.  The centerpiece of my life was the Vietnam War. I was there the day it started. I led the first bombing raid against North Vietnam. I was there the day it ended
column3: and I was there for everything in between. Ten years in Vietnam
column4: aerial combat
column5: and torture. I know things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world. I know some things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world.  And I know how governments
column6: how American governments can be -- can be courageous
column7: and how they can be callow. And that's important. That's one thing I'm an insider on.  I was the leader of the underground of the American pilots who were shot down in prison in North Vietnam. You should know that the American character displayed in those dungeons by those fine men was a thing of beauty.  I look back on those years as the beginning of wisdom
column8: learning everything a man can learn about the vulnerabilities and the strengths that are ours as Americans.  Why am I here tonight? I am here because I have in my brain and in my heart what it takes to lead America through tough times.

column3: 1)	" Good evening. It's great to be here in Atlanta for this debate where America will be showcased to the world when the 1996 Olympics are put on right here. It's appropriate because in a real sense
column4: our discussion this evening will be about what kind of nation we want to be 4 years from now. It's also a pleasure to be with my 2 opponents this evening. Admiral Stockdale
column5: may I say it's a special honor to share this stage with you. Those of us who served in Vietnam looked at you as a national hero even before you were awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor. And Mr. Vice President -- Dan
column6: if I may -- it was 16 years ago that you and I went to the Congress on the very first day together. I'll make you a deal this evening. If you don't try to compare George Bush to Harry Truman
column7: I won't compare you to Jack Kennedy.  (APPLAUSE)  Harry Truman --

column1: Do you remember the last time someone compared themselves to Jack Kennedy? Do you remember what they said?

column3: assumed the presidency when Franklin Roosevelt died here in Georgia -- only one of many occasions when fate thrust a vice president into the Oval Office in a time of crisis. It's something to think about during the debate this evening. But our real discussion is going to be about change. Bill Clinton and I stand for change because we don't believe our nation can stand 4 more years of what we've had under George Bush and Dan Quayle. When the recession came they were like a deer caught in the headlights -- paralyzed into inaction
column4: blinded to the suffering and pain of bankruptcies and people who were unemployed. We have an environmental crisis
column5: a health insurance crisis
column6: substandard education. It is time for a change.  Bill Clinton and I want to get our country moving forward again
column7: put our people back to work
column8: and create a bright future for the US of America.

column3: Senator Gore
column4: for reminding me about my performance in the 1988 vice presidential debate. This is 1992
column5: Bill Clinton is running against President George Bush. There are 2 things that I'm going to stress during this debate: one
column6: Bill Clinton's economic plan and his agenda will make matters much
column7: much worse -- he will raise your taxes
column8: he will increase spending
column9: he will make government bigger
column10: jobs will be lost; second
column11: Bill Clinton does not have the strength nor the character to be president of the US. (APPLAUSE)  Let us look at the agendas. President Bush wants to hold the line on taxes
column12: Bill Clinton wants to raise taxes. President Bush is for a balanced budget amendment
column13: Bill Clinton is opposed to it. We want to reform the legal system because it's too costly
column14: Bill Clinton wants the status quo. We want to reform the health care system
column15: Bill Clinton wants to ration health care. Bill Clinton wants to empower government
column16: we want to empower people.  In St. Louis
column17: Missouri
column19: Bill Clinton said this: ""America is the mockery of the world."" He is wrong.  At some time during these next 4 years there is going to be a crisis -- there will be an international crisis. I can't tell you where it's going to be
column20: I can't even tell you the circumstances -- but it will happen. We need a president who has the experience
column21: who has been tested
column22: who has the integrity and qualifications to handle the crisis. The president has been tested
column23: the president has the integrity and the character. The choice is yours.  You need to have a president you can trust. Can you really trust Bill Clinton?

column1: Who am I? Why am I here? (Laughter and applause)  I'm not a politician -- everybody knows that. So don't expect me to use the language of the Washington insider. Thirty-seven years in the Navy
column2: and only one of them up there in Washington. And now I'm an academic.  The centerpiece of my life was the Vietnam War. I was there the day it started. I led the first bombing raid against North Vietnam. I was there the day it ended
column3: and I was there for everything in between. Ten years in Vietnam
column4: aerial combat
column5: and torture. I know things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world. I know some things about the Vietnam War better than anybody in the world.  And I know how governments
column6: how American governments can be -- can be courageous
column7: and how they can be callow. And that's important. That's one thing I'm an insider on.  I was the leader of the underground of the American pilots who were shot down in prison in North Vietnam. You should know that the American character displayed in those dungeons by those fine men was a thing of beauty.  I look back on those years as the beginning of wisdom
column8: learning everything a man can learn about the vulnerabilities and the strengths that are ours as Americans.  Why am I here tonight? I am here because I have in my brain and in my heart what it takes to lead America through tough times.

column1: It is time for a change. You should know that the American character displayed in those dungeons by those fine men was a thing of beauty.  I look back on those years as the beginning of wisdom
column8: learning everything a man can learn about the vulnerabilities and the strengths that are ours as Americans.  Why am I here tonight? I am here because I have in my brain and in my heart what it takes to lead America through tough times.

column3: 3)	" The lifeblood of our economy is investment. And right now when we pay $350 -- we borrow $350 billion a year it saps the money markets and the private investors are not getting their share. What we do is work on that budget by an aggressive program
column4: not a painful program
column5: so that we can start borrowing less money and getting more investment money on the street through entrepreneurs who can build factories
column6: who will hire people
column7: and maybe we'll start manufacturing goods here in this country again. That's -- that's my answer.

column1: Bill Clinton's top priority is putting America back to work. Bill Clinton and I will create good
column3: the same way he has done in his state. Bill Clinton has created high-wage manufacturing jobs at 10 times the national average and in fact according to the statistics coming from the Bush-Quayle Labor Dept
column4: for the last 2 years in a role Bill Clinton's state has been number one among all 50 in the creation of jobs in the private sector. By contrast
column5: in the nation as a whole
column6: during the last 4 years
column7: it is the first time since the presidency of Herbert Hoover
column8: that we have gone for a 4-year period with fewer jobs at the end of that 4-year period than we had at the beginning.  And look at manufacturing. We have lost 1.4 million jobs in manufacturing under George Bush and Dan Quayle. They have even -- we learned 2 weeks ago -- taken our tax dollars and subsidized the moving of US factories to foreign countries. Now don't deny it because 60 Minutes and Nightline and the nation's newspapers have investigated this very carefully.  (Laughter.)  When are you going to stop using our tax dollars to shut down American factories and move 'em to foreign countries and throw Americans out of work?

column2: don't always believe what you see on television. (APPLAUSE.)  Let me tell you: the media have been wrong before. We have never subsidized any country -- or any company to move from the US to Latin America. You know full well the Caribbean Basin Initiative
column3: you've supported that.

column1: You voted for it and your record --

column2: we'll -- we'll have a lot of interesting debate after this debate. Our people will be glad to furnish the press
column3: if they're interested
column4: in Senator Gore's voting record on the Caribbean Basin Initiative. But let's talk -- you know
column5: you keep talking about trickle-down economics and all this stuff
column6: about the worst economy since Hoover. It is a bad economy. It's a tough economy. The question isn't -- it's not who you're going to blame; its what are you going to do about it? Your proposal it to raise $150 billion in taxes. To raise $220 billion in new spending.

column1: How is raising taxes going to help small business? How is raising taxes going to help the farmer? How is raising taxes going to help the consumer in America? I submit to you that raising taxes will make matters much

column2: we've got to re -- we've got to clean out the barn
column3: if I may quote my boss
column4: and start getting this investment money on the street so we can get
column5: and encourage entrepreneurs to build factories. We -- the program is out there. It's a put-together thing that requires some sacrifice
column6: but not excessive
column7: and we are willing to move forward in -- on a 5-year clip to put us back where we can start over and get -- get this nation straightened out.

column2: the difference between the Perot- Stockdale plan and the Clinton-Gore plan is that Ross Perot's plan concentrates almost exclusively on balancing the budget and reducing the budget deficit
column3: and the danger is that if that is the only goal it could throw our nation back into an even worse recession. Bill Clinton and I have a detailed 5-year budget plan to create good jobs
column4: cut the budget deficit in half
column5: and eliminate the investment deficit in order to get our economy moving forward again. We have a $20-billion infrastructure fund to create a nationwide network of high-speed rail
column6: for example
column7: and what are called information superhighways to open up a whole universe of knowledge for our young people and to help our universities and companies that rely on new advances in the information revolution. We also have tax incentives for investment in job-creating activities
column8: not the kind of encouragement for short-term rip-offs like the proposal that we have had from George Bush.  But I want to return and say one more time: you have used our tax dollars to subsidize the recruitment of US companies to move overseas and throw Americans out of work. In Decaturville
column9: Tennessee
column10: not very far from my home
column11: a factory was shut down right there when they were solicited by officials paid with US taxpayers' money
column12: and then the replacement workers in a foreign country were trained with our tax dollars and then their imports were subsidized coming back into the US.  When are you going to stop that program?

column1: We do not have any program that encourages companies to close down here and to go and invest on foreign soil. That is absolutely outrageous. Of course American businesses do have business abroad; we've got global competition. We want businesses to expand. Do you realize this
column3: that every job that's overseas there's 3 jobs back here to support that. But never have we ever
column4: nor would we
column5: support the idea of someone closing down a factory here and moving overseas. That's just totally ridiculous.

column1: It's going on right now; it happened in Tennessee
column3: Tennessee. When George Bush went to Nashville
column4: the employees who lost their jobs asked to meet with --

column1: I talked with them. Let me tell you what they're feeling. Some of them are in their 50s and 60s. They want to know where they're going to get new jobs when their jobs have been destroyed. And there are 1.4 million manufacturing jobs that have been lost because of the policies of you and George Bush. Do you seriously believe that we ought to continue the same policies that have created the worst economy since the Great Depression?
I hope that when you talked to those people you said: and the first thing that Bill Clinton and I are going to do is to raise $150 billion in new taxes.
And the first -- that is part of your plan.
A hundred and fifty billion dollars in new taxes. Well
column2: you're going to disavow your plan.
you know what you're doing? You're pulling a Clinton. (Laughter)  And you know what a Clinton is? And you know what Clinton is? A Clinton is
column3: is what he says -- he says one thing one day and another thing the next day -- you try to have both sides of the issues. The fact of the matter is that you are proposing $150 billion in new taxes.

column1: And I hope that you talk to the people in Tennessee --
You can say it all you want but it doesn't make it true.

-- going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I'm sure what you didn't talk to them about was about how we're going to reform the health care system
column2: like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance. I'm sure one other thing that you didn't talk to them about
column3: Senator
column4: and that is legal reform
column5: because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. Why should an American company have to spend 15 to 20 times on product liability and insurance costs compared to a company in Japan or a company in Germany or somewhere else? That's not right. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won't pass it.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 3)	" The lifeblood of our economy is investment. And right now when we pay $350 -- we borrow $350 billion a year it saps the money markets and the private investors are not getting their share. What we do is work on that budget by an aggressive program
column4: not a painful program
column5: so that we can start borrowing less money and getting more investment money on the street through entrepreneurs who can build factories
column6: who will hire people
column7: and maybe we'll start manufacturing goods here in this country again. That's -- that's my answer.

column1: Bill Clinton's top priority is putting America back to work. Bill Clinton and I will create good
column3: the same way he has done in his state. Bill Clinton has created high-wage manufacturing jobs at 10 times the national average and in fact according to the statistics coming from the Bush-Quayle Labor Dept
column4: for the last 2 years in a role Bill Clinton's state has been number one among all 50 in the creation of jobs in the private sector. By contrast
column5: in the nation as a whole
column6: during the last 4 years
column7: it is the first time since the presidency of Herbert Hoover
column8: that we have gone for a 4-year period with fewer jobs at the end of that 4-year period than we had at the beginning.  And look at manufacturing. We have lost 1.4 million jobs in manufacturing under George Bush and Dan Quayle. They have even -- we learned 2 weeks ago -- taken our tax dollars and subsidized the moving of US factories to foreign countries. Now don't deny it because 60 Minutes and Nightline and the nation's newspapers have investigated this very carefully.  (Laughter.)  When are you going to stop using our tax dollars to shut down American factories and move 'em to foreign countries and throw Americans out of work?

column2: don't always believe what you see on television. (APPLAUSE.)  Let me tell you: the media have been wrong before. We have never subsidized any country -- or any company to move from the US to Latin America. You know full well the Caribbean Basin Initiative
column3: you've supported that.

column1: You voted for it and your record --

column2: we'll -- we'll have a lot of interesting debate after this debate. Our people will be glad to furnish the press
column3: if they're interested
column4: in Senator Gore's voting record on the Caribbean Basin Initiative. But let's talk -- you know
column5: you keep talking about trickle-down economics and all this stuff
column6: about the worst economy since Hoover. It is a bad economy. It's a tough economy. The question isn't -- it's not who you're going to blame; its what are you going to do about it? Your proposal it to raise $150 billion in taxes. To raise $220 billion in new spending.

column1: How is raising taxes going to help small business? How is raising taxes going to help the farmer? How is raising taxes going to help the consumer in America? I submit to you that raising taxes will make matters much

column2: we've got to re -- we've got to clean out the barn
column3: if I may quote my boss
column4: and start getting this investment money on the street so we can get
column5: and encourage entrepreneurs to build factories. We -- the program is out there. It's a put-together thing that requires some sacrifice
column6: but not excessive
column7: and we are willing to move forward in -- on a 5-year clip to put us back where we can start over and get -- get this nation straightened out.

column2: the difference between the Perot- Stockdale plan and the Clinton-Gore plan is that Ross Perot's plan concentrates almost exclusively on balancing the budget and reducing the budget deficit
column3: and the danger is that if that is the only goal it could throw our nation back into an even worse recession. Bill Clinton and I have a detailed 5-year budget plan to create good jobs
column4: cut the budget deficit in half
column5: and eliminate the investment deficit in order to get our economy moving forward again. We have a $20-billion infrastructure fund to create a nationwide network of high-speed rail
column6: for example
column7: and what are called information superhighways to open up a whole universe of knowledge for our young people and to help our universities and companies that rely on new advances in the information revolution. We also have tax incentives for investment in job-creating activities
column8: not the kind of encouragement for short-term rip-offs like the proposal that we have had from George Bush.  But I want to return and say one more time: you have used our tax dollars to subsidize the recruitment of US companies to move overseas and throw Americans out of work. In Decaturville
column9: Tennessee
column10: not very far from my home
column11: a factory was shut down right there when they were solicited by officials paid with US taxpayers' money
column12: and then the replacement workers in a foreign country were trained with our tax dollars and then their imports were subsidized coming back into the US.  When are you going to stop that program?

column1: We do not have any program that encourages companies to close down here and to go and invest on foreign soil. That is absolutely outrageous. Of course American businesses do have business abroad; we've got global competition. We want businesses to expand. Do you realize this
column3: that every job that's overseas there's 3 jobs back here to support that. But never have we ever
column4: nor would we
column5: support the idea of someone closing down a factory here and moving overseas. That's just totally ridiculous.

column1: It's going on right now; it happened in Tennessee
column3: Tennessee. When George Bush went to Nashville
column4: the employees who lost their jobs asked to meet with --

column1: I talked with them. Let me tell you what they're feeling. Some of them are in their 50s and 60s. They want to know where they're going to get new jobs when their jobs have been destroyed. And there are 1.4 million manufacturing jobs that have been lost because of the policies of you and George Bush. Do you seriously believe that we ought to continue the same policies that have created the worst economy since the Great Depression?
I hope that when you talked to those people you said: and the first thing that Bill Clinton and I are going to do is to raise $150 billion in new taxes.
And the first -- that is part of your plan.
A hundred and fifty billion dollars in new taxes. Well
column2: you're going to disavow your plan.
you know what you're doing? You're pulling a Clinton. (Laughter)  And you know what a Clinton is? And you know what Clinton is? A Clinton is
column3: is what he says -- he says one thing one day and another thing the next day -- you try to have both sides of the issues. The fact of the matter is that you are proposing $150 billion in new taxes.

column1: And I hope that you talk to the people in Tennessee --
You can say it all you want but it doesn't make it true.

-- going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I'm sure what you didn't talk to them about was about how we're going to reform the health care system
column2: like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance. I'm sure one other thing that you didn't talk to them about
column3: Senator
column4: and that is legal reform
column5: because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. Why should an American company have to spend 15 to 20 times on product liability and insurance costs compared to a company in Japan or a company in Germany or somewhere else? That's not right. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won't pass it.  (APPLAUSE)

column2: don't always believe what you see on television. (APPLAUSE.)  Let me tell you: the media have been wrong before. We have never subsidized any country -- or any company to move from the US to Latin America. You know full well the Caribbean Basin Initiative
column3: you've supported that.

column1: You voted for it and your record --

column2: we'll -- we'll have a lot of interesting debate after this debate. Our people will be glad to furnish the press
column3: if they're interested
column4: in Senator Gore's voting record on the Caribbean Basin Initiative. But let's talk -- you know
column5: you keep talking about trickle-down economics and all this stuff
column6: about the worst economy since Hoover. It is a bad economy. It's a tough economy. The question isn't -- it's not who you're going to blame; its what are you going to do about it? Your proposal it to raise $150 billion in taxes. To raise $220 billion in new spending.

column1: How is raising taxes going to help small business? How is raising taxes going to help the farmer? How is raising taxes going to help the consumer in America? I submit to you that raising taxes will make matters much

column2: we've got to re -- we've got to clean out the barn
column3: if I may quote my boss
column4: and start getting this investment money on the street so we can get
column5: and encourage entrepreneurs to build factories. We -- the program is out there. It's a put-together thing that requires some sacrifice
column6: but not excessive
column7: and we are willing to move forward in -- on a 5-year clip to put us back where we can start over and get -- get this nation straightened out.

column2: the difference between the Perot- Stockdale plan and the Clinton-Gore plan is that Ross Perot's plan concentrates almost exclusively on balancing the budget and reducing the budget deficit
column3: and the danger is that if that is the only goal it could throw our nation back into an even worse recession. Bill Clinton and I have a detailed 5-year budget plan to create good jobs
column4: cut the budget deficit in half
column5: and eliminate the investment deficit in order to get our economy moving forward again. We have a $20-billion infrastructure fund to create a nationwide network of high-speed rail
column6: for example
column7: and what are called information superhighways to open up a whole universe of knowledge for our young people and to help our universities and companies that rely on new advances in the information revolution. We also have tax incentives for investment in job-creating activities
column8: not the kind of encouragement for short-term rip-offs like the proposal that we have had from George Bush.  But I want to return and say one more time: you have used our tax dollars to subsidize the recruitment of US companies to move overseas and throw Americans out of work. In Decaturville
column9: Tennessee
column10: not very far from my home
column11: a factory was shut down right there when they were solicited by officials paid with US taxpayers' money
column12: and then the replacement workers in a foreign country were trained with our tax dollars and then their imports were subsidized coming back into the US.  When are you going to stop that program?

column1: We do not have any program that encourages companies to close down here and to go and invest on foreign soil. That is absolutely outrageous. Of course American businesses do have business abroad; we've got global competition. We want businesses to expand. Do you realize this
column3: that every job that's overseas there's 3 jobs back here to support that. But never have we ever
column4: nor would we
column5: support the idea of someone closing down a factory here and moving overseas. That's just totally ridiculous.

column1: It's going on right now; it happened in Tennessee
column3: Tennessee. When George Bush went to Nashville
column4: the employees who lost their jobs asked to meet with --

column1: I talked with them. Let me tell you what they're feeling. Some of them are in their 50s and 60s. They want to know where they're going to get new jobs when their jobs have been destroyed. And there are 1.4 million manufacturing jobs that have been lost because of the policies of you and George Bush. Do you seriously believe that we ought to continue the same policies that have created the worst economy since the Great Depression?
I hope that when you talked to those people you said: and the first thing that Bill Clinton and I are going to do is to raise $150 billion in new taxes.
And the first -- that is part of your plan.
A hundred and fifty billion dollars in new taxes. Well
column2: you're going to disavow your plan.
you know what you're doing? You're pulling a Clinton. (Laughter)  And you know what a Clinton is? And you know what Clinton is? A Clinton is
column3: is what he says -- he says one thing one day and another thing the next day -- you try to have both sides of the issues. The fact of the matter is that you are proposing $150 billion in new taxes.

column1: And I hope that you talk to the people in Tennessee --
You can say it all you want but it doesn't make it true.

-- going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I'm sure what you didn't talk to them about was about how we're going to reform the health care system
column2: like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance. I'm sure one other thing that you didn't talk to them about
column3: Senator
column4: and that is legal reform
column5: because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. Why should an American company have to spend 15 to 20 times on product liability and insurance costs compared to a company in Japan or a company in Germany or somewhere else? That's not right. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won't pass it.  (APPLAUSE)

you know what you're doing? You're pulling a Clinton. (Laughter)  And you know what a Clinton is? And you know what Clinton is? A Clinton is

column1: And I hope that you talk to the people in Tennessee --
You can say it all you want but it doesn't make it true.

-- going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I'm sure what you didn't talk to them about was about how we're going to reform the health care system
column2: like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance. I'm sure one other thing that you didn't talk to them about
column3: Senator
column4: and that is legal reform
column5: because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. Why should an American company have to spend 15 to 20 times on product liability and insurance costs compared to a company in Japan or a company in Germany or somewhere else? That's not right. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won't pass it.  (APPLAUSE)

When are you going to stop using our tax dollars to shut down American factories and move 'em to foreign countries and throw Americans out of work?

column1: I talked with them. Let me tell you what they're feeling. Some of them are in their 50s and 60s. They want to know where they're going to get new jobs when their jobs have been destroyed. And there are 1.4 million manufacturing jobs that have been lost because of the policies of you and George Bush. Do you seriously believe that we ought to continue the same policies that have created the worst economy since the Great Depression?
I hope that when you talked to those people you said: and the first thing that Bill Clinton and I are going to do is to raise $150 billion in new taxes.
And the first -- that is part of your plan.
A hundred and fifty billion dollars in new taxes. Well
column2: you're going to disavow your plan.
you know what you're doing? You're pulling a Clinton. (Laughter)  And you know what a Clinton is? And you know what Clinton is? A Clinton is
column3: is what he says -- he says one thing one day and another thing the next day -- you try to have both sides of the issues. The fact of the matter is that you are proposing $150 billion in new taxes.

column1: And I hope that you talk to the people in Tennessee --
You can say it all you want but it doesn't make it true.

-- going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I'm sure what you didn't talk to them about was about how we're going to reform the health care system
column2: like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance. I'm sure one other thing that you didn't talk to them about
column3: Senator
column4: and that is legal reform
column5: because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. Why should an American company have to spend 15 to 20 times on product liability and insurance costs compared to a company in Japan or a company in Germany or somewhere else? That's not right. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won't pass it.  (APPLAUSE)

column4: for the last 2 years in a role Bill Clinton's state has been number one among all 50 in the creation of jobs in the private sector. By contrast

column8: that we have gone for a 4-year period with fewer jobs at the end of that 4-year period than we had at the beginning.  And look at manufacturing. We have lost 1.4 million jobs in manufacturing under George Bush and Dan Quayle. They have even -- we learned 2 weeks ago -- taken our tax dollars and subsidized the moving of US factories to foreign countries. Now don't deny it because 60 Minutes and Nightline and the nation's newspapers have investigated this very carefully.  (Laughter.)  When are you going to stop using our tax dollars to shut down American factories and move 'em to foreign countries and throw Americans out of work?

column3: 3)	" The lifeblood of our economy is investment. And right now when we pay $350 -- we borrow $350 billion a year it saps the money markets and the private investors are not getting their share. What we do is work on that budget by an aggressive program
column4: not a painful program

column1: Bill Clinton's top priority is putting America back to work. Bill Clinton and I will create good
column3: the same way he has done in his state. Bill Clinton has created high-wage manufacturing jobs at 10 times the national average and in fact according to the statistics coming from the Bush-Quayle Labor Dept
column4: for the last 2 years in a role Bill Clinton's state has been number one among all 50 in the creation of jobs in the private sector. By contrast
column5: in the nation as a whole
column6: during the last 4 years
column7: it is the first time since the presidency of Herbert Hoover
column8: that we have gone for a 4-year period with fewer jobs at the end of that 4-year period than we had at the beginning.  And look at manufacturing. We have lost 1.4 million jobs in manufacturing under George Bush and Dan Quayle. They have even -- we learned 2 weeks ago -- taken our tax dollars and subsidized the moving of US factories to foreign countries. Now don't deny it because 60 Minutes and Nightline and the nation's newspapers have investigated this very carefully.  (Laughter.)  When are you going to stop using our tax dollars to shut down American factories and move 'em to foreign countries and throw Americans out of work?

column2: don't always believe what you see on television. (APPLAUSE.)  Let me tell you: the media have been wrong before. We have never subsidized any country -- or any company to move from the US to Latin America. You know full well the Caribbean Basin Initiative
column3: you've supported that.

column1: You voted for it and your record --

column3: if they're interested
column4: in Senator Gore's voting record on the Caribbean Basin Initiative. But let's talk -- you know
column5: you keep talking about trickle-down economics and all this stuff
column6: about the worst economy since Hoover. It is a bad economy. It's a tough economy. The question isn't -- it's not who you're going to blame; its what are you going to do about it? Your proposal it to raise $150 billion in taxes. To raise $220 billion in new spending.

column1: How is raising taxes going to help small business? How is raising taxes going to help the farmer? How is raising taxes going to help the consumer in America? I submit to you that raising taxes will make matters much

column5: and encourage entrepreneurs to build factories. We -- the program is out there. It's a put-together thing that requires some sacrifice
column6: but not excessive
column7: and we are willing to move forward in -- on a 5-year clip to put us back where we can start over and get -- get this nation straightened out.

column2: the difference between the Perot- Stockdale plan and the Clinton-Gore plan is that Ross Perot's plan concentrates almost exclusively on balancing the budget and reducing the budget deficit
column3: and the danger is that if that is the only goal it could throw our nation back into an even worse recession. Bill Clinton and I have a detailed 5-year budget plan to create good jobs
column4: cut the budget deficit in half
column5: and eliminate the investment deficit in order to get our economy moving forward again. We have a $20-billion infrastructure fund to create a nationwide network of high-speed rail
column6: for example
column7: and what are called information superhighways to open up a whole universe of knowledge for our young people and to help our universities and companies that rely on new advances in the information revolution. We also have tax incentives for investment in job-creating activities
column8: not the kind of encouragement for short-term rip-offs like the proposal that we have had from George Bush.  But I want to return and say one more time: you have used our tax dollars to subsidize the recruitment of US companies to move overseas and throw Americans out of work. In Decaturville
column9: Tennessee
column10: not very far from my home
column11: a factory was shut down right there when they were solicited by officials paid with US taxpayers' money
column12: and then the replacement workers in a foreign country were trained with our tax dollars and then their imports were subsidized coming back into the US.  When are you going to stop that program?

column1: We do not have any program that encourages companies to close down here and to go and invest on foreign soil. That is absolutely outrageous. Of course American businesses do have business abroad; we've got global competition. We want businesses to expand. Do you realize this
column3: that every job that's overseas there's 3 jobs back here to support that. But never have we ever
column4: nor would we
column5: support the idea of someone closing down a factory here and moving overseas. That's just totally ridiculous.

column1: I talked with them. Let me tell you what they're feeling. Some of them are in their 50s and 60s. They want to know where they're going to get new jobs when their jobs have been destroyed. And there are 1.4 million manufacturing jobs that have been lost because of the policies of you and George Bush. Do you seriously believe that we ought to continue the same policies that have created the worst economy since the Great Depression?
I hope that when you talked to those people you said: and the first thing that Bill Clinton and I are going to do is to raise $150 billion in new taxes.

you know what you're doing? You're pulling a Clinton. (Laughter)  And you know what a Clinton is? And you know what Clinton is? A Clinton is

column1: And I hope that you talk to the people in Tennessee --
You can say it all you want but it doesn't make it true.

-- going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I'm sure what you didn't talk to them about was about how we're going to reform the health care system
column2: like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance. I'm sure one other thing that you didn't talk to them about
column3: Senator

column5: because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. Why should an American company have to spend 15 to 20 times on product liability and insurance costs compared to a company in Japan or a company in Germany or somewhere else? That's not right. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won't pass it.  (APPLAUSE)

column6: about the worst economy since Hoover. It is a bad economy. It's a tough economy. The question isn't -- it's not who you're going to blame; its what are you going to do about it? Your proposal it to raise $150 billion in taxes. To raise $220 billion in new spending.

column1: How is raising taxes going to help small business? How is raising taxes going to help the farmer? How is raising taxes going to help the consumer in America? I submit to you that raising taxes will make matters much

column2: we've got to re -- we've got to clean out the barn
column3: if I may quote my boss
column4: and start getting this investment money on the street so we can get
column5: and encourage entrepreneurs to build factories. We -- the program is out there. It's a put-together thing that requires some sacrifice
column6: but not excessive
column7: and we are willing to move forward in -- on a 5-year clip to put us back where we can start over and get -- get this nation straightened out.

column2: the difference between the Perot- Stockdale plan and the Clinton-Gore plan is that Ross Perot's plan concentrates almost exclusively on balancing the budget and reducing the budget deficit
column3: and the danger is that if that is the only goal it could throw our nation back into an even worse recession. Bill Clinton and I have a detailed 5-year budget plan to create good jobs
column4: cut the budget deficit in half
column5: and eliminate the investment deficit in order to get our economy moving forward again. We have a $20-billion infrastructure fund to create a nationwide network of high-speed rail
column6: for example
column7: and what are called information superhighways to open up a whole universe of knowledge for our young people and to help our universities and companies that rely on new advances in the information revolution. We also have tax incentives for investment in job-creating activities
column8: not the kind of encouragement for short-term rip-offs like the proposal that we have had from George Bush.  But I want to return and say one more time: you have used our tax dollars to subsidize the recruitment of US companies to move overseas and throw Americans out of work. In Decaturville
column9: Tennessee
column10: not very far from my home
column11: a factory was shut down right there when they were solicited by officials paid with US taxpayers' money
column12: and then the replacement workers in a foreign country were trained with our tax dollars and then their imports were subsidized coming back into the US.  When are you going to stop that program?

column1: We do not have any program that encourages companies to close down here and to go and invest on foreign soil. That is absolutely outrageous. Of course American businesses do have business abroad; we've got global competition. We want businesses to expand. Do you realize this
column3: that every job that's overseas there's 3 jobs back here to support that. But never have we ever
column4: nor would we
column5: support the idea of someone closing down a factory here and moving overseas. That's just totally ridiculous.

column1: It's going on right now; it happened in Tennessee
column3: Tennessee. When George Bush went to Nashville
column4: the employees who lost their jobs asked to meet with --

column1: I talked with them. Let me tell you what they're feeling. Some of them are in their 50s and 60s. They want to know where they're going to get new jobs when their jobs have been destroyed. And there are 1.4 million manufacturing jobs that have been lost because of the policies of you and George Bush. Do you seriously believe that we ought to continue the same policies that have created the worst economy since the Great Depression?
I hope that when you talked to those people you said: and the first thing that Bill Clinton and I are going to do is to raise $150 billion in new taxes.
And the first -- that is part of your plan.
A hundred and fifty billion dollars in new taxes. Well
column2: you're going to disavow your plan.
you know what you're doing? You're pulling a Clinton. (Laughter)  And you know what a Clinton is? And you know what Clinton is? A Clinton is
column3: is what he says -- he says one thing one day and another thing the next day -- you try to have both sides of the issues. The fact of the matter is that you are proposing $150 billion in new taxes.

column1: And I hope that you talk to the people in Tennessee --
You can say it all you want but it doesn't make it true.

-- going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I'm sure what you didn't talk to them about was about how we're going to reform the health care system
column2: like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance. I'm sure one other thing that you didn't talk to them about
column3: Senator
column4: and that is legal reform
column5: because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. Why should an American company have to spend 15 to 20 times on product liability and insurance costs compared to a company in Japan or a company in Germany or somewhere else? That's not right. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won't pass it.  (APPLAUSE)

-- going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I'm sure what you didn't talk to them about was about how we're going to reform the health care system
column2: like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance. I'm sure one other thing that you didn't talk to them about
column3: Senator
column4: and that is legal reform
column5: because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won't pass it.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: I talked with them. Let me tell you what they're feeling. Some of them are in their 50s and 60s. They want to know where they're going to get new jobs when their jobs have been destroyed. And there are 1.4 million manufacturing jobs that have been lost because of the policies of you and George Bush. column1: And I hope that you talk to the people in Tennessee --
You can say it all you want but it doesn't make it true.

-- going to have new taxes. I hope you talked to them about the fact that you were going to increase spending to $220 billion. I'm sure what you didn't talk to them about was about how we're going to reform the health care system
column2: like the president wants to do. He wants to go out and to reform the health care system so that every American will have available to them affordable health insurance. I'm sure one other thing that you didn't talk to them about
column3: Senator
column4: and that is legal reform
column5: because your position on legal reform is the status quo. And yet you talk about foreign competition. Why should an American company have to spend 15 to 20 times on product liability and insurance costs compared to a company in Japan or a company in Germany or somewhere else? That's not right. We have product liability reform legislation on Capitol Hill. It will create jobs. And a Democratic Congress won't pass it.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column5: said ""Read my lips -- no new taxes."" (Laughter and applause)  And you know what?

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: in case you've forgotten
column4: Dan
column5: said ""Read my lips -- no new taxes."" (Laughter and applause)  And you know what?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests

column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.
