column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly

column14: Ross

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes

column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes

column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd

column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests

column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column10: he said

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts

column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion

column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany

We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts

column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts

column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd

column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice

column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
