column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact

column21: and under the START I treaty

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column4: Dan
column5: said ""Read my lips -- no new taxes."" (Laughter and applause)  And you know what?

column10: he said

column15: Dan? Is he going to -- what's your role in this going to be?  (Laughter and applause)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column4: Dan
column5: said ""Read my lips -- no new taxes."" (Laughter and applause)  And you know what?

column7: if you win
column8: then James Baker's going to go back to be secretary of state; then a week later
column9: in the debate a few nights ago
column10: he said
column11: no
column12: after the election
column13: if we win
column14: James Baker is going to be in charge of domestic policy. Which is it
column15: Dan? Is he going to -- what's your role in this going to be?  (Laughter and applause)

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column2: I'd like to respond first to you
column3: Admiral Stockdale. Under the details of our 5-year budget plan
column4: we do propose more in defense cuts than George Bush and Dan Quayle
column5: but only 5 % more. Admiral Crowe
column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: I've known him --

column1: -- the military portions of our plan
column2: even though he was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs under George Bush
column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan
column4: even though I believe he was the architect of Ross Perot's economic plan. Now when I heard George Bush say at the convention in Houston
column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact
column19: that every single one of those SS-18s is still there
column21: and under the START I treaty
column22: only half of the silos are supposed to be dismantled
column23: and there is no deal to get rid of the other half?  Didn't the president make a mistake there?

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: I want to respond to that
column2: I want to respond to that. George Bush
column3: in case you've forgotten
column4: Dan
column5: said ""Read my lips -- no new taxes."" (Laughter and applause)  And you know what?

column1: I didn't think I was going to hear that tonight.

column3: let me finish.

column1: He also said he wanted to be the environmental president; then he went on to say he wanted to be the education president. Then he said that he wouldn't raise taxes again -- no
column3: ever
column4: ever. Then the next day his spokesman
column5: Marlin Fitzwater
column6: came out and said that's not a pledge. Then 2 weeks ago he said that after the election
column7: if you win
column8: then James Baker's going to go back to be secretary of state; then a week later
column9: in the debate a few nights ago
column10: he said
column11: no
column12: after the election
column13: if we win
column14: James Baker is going to be in charge of domestic policy. Which is it
column15: Dan? Is he going to -- what's your role in this going to be?  (Laughter and applause)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

column3: 4)	" Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense. He and I have both fought for change within the Democratic Party as well as within the country. In the aftermath of the Cold War
column4: the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat. For example
column5: George Bush wants to maintain at least 150
column6: 000 American soldiers in Europe
column7: even though World War II ended 50 years ago. Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans
column8: who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe.  We believe that we can make savings in our defense budget and at the same time
column9: improve our national security.  Now
column10: for those who are affected by the cutbacks
column11: whether they come from George Bush or Bill Clinton and me -- the difference is
column12: Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program so that those who won the Cold War will not be left out in the cold. We want to put them to work
column13: building an infrastructure and an economy here in this country for the '90's and the next century.

column1: We won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because we invested in our military. We didn't win the Cold -- we won the Cold War because we invested in national security. We won the Cold War because America had the political will and made the right decisions. Yes
column2: we can make the cuts in defense and we have. Bill Clinton wants to cut defense another $60 billion. I'd say to the defense workers in California and elsewhere
column3: a $60 billion defense cut is going to cut a lot of jobs out. Yes
column4: we are making a conversion and we can go to a civil space rather than having defense -- or the defense industry. Well
column5: let me say this: we would not have won the Cold War if we had listened to Senator Gore and his crowd
column6: and had supported a nuclear freeze. If you would have supported that attitude -- if you would have supported that attitude
column7: we would not have won the Cold War. We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.  (APPLAUSE.)

column3: in terms of the dollar cuts
column4: as they stand on our plans now
column5: show us almost the same as the vice president's. But we'd note that Mr. -- Governor Clinton's plan is almost twice as much a cut as either one of us. I've been through the end of World War II
column6: and the surprise beginning of Korea
column7: to see how we -- it cost us more money because we overcut the defense budget in the first place. I don't say that -- (APPLAUSE.)  So I think that should be eyed with great suspicion
column8: people that are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment prematurely.  Now there's other differences between the Perot approach and what we see up here on either side of me
column9: and that has to do with we want to focus our interests
column10: economic and military
column11: more to the Pacific. We figure that we are generally going along with any sort of a troop removal from Europe. So that's still another face of this puzzle.

column6: who I think was one of your classmates in Annapolis --

column3: and John White has endorsed the economic aspects of our plan

column5: that when he heard the phrase ""we won the Cold War
column6: it made him wonder who the ""we"" was. Well
column7: I want to tell you
column8: President Bush
column9: the ""we"" is the people of the US of America. This wasn't a partisan victory that came suddenly
column10: a few months after you took the oath of office. This started with Harry Truman and it was a bipartisan effort from the very beginning. George Bush taking credit for the Berlin Wall coming down is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise.  (APPLAUSE.)  And I want to
column11: I want to add -- I want to add one other thing
column12: because in the debate a few nights ago
column13: I think President Bush made a very serious misstatement of fact in response to Ross Perot. It was kind of a little lecture he gave to Ross Perot when he said those SS-18s are gone
column14: Ross
column15: that's done. He -- he reached a deal with Boris Yeltsin to completely remove them so we can all sleep safely without any fear tonight.  But you know what? They thought they were going to get that deal
column16: but when he took the person in charge of the negotiations out of the State Dept and put him in charge of the reelection campaign
column17: the deal unraveled and now there is no START II deal at all. In fact there are serious problems.  Isn't it a fact

column21: and under the START I treaty

column1: The president does have a commitment from Boris Yeltsin to eliminate the SS-18s. That is a commitment to --
Let's talk about getting agreements. You know
column2: the president of the US doesn't just negotiate with your friends in Congress; the president of the US deals on the international scene. He's got to deal with the president of Russia
column3: he's got to deal with the chancellor of Germany
column4: the prime minister of Britain
column5: the president of France
column6: the prime minister of Japan -- he's got to deal with a whole host of leaders around the world. And the leaders sit down and they will negotiate
column7: and they will come to agreements with people that they trust. And this is a fundamental problem with Bill Clinton
column8: is trust and character. It is not the issue of how he avoided military service 20-some years ago; it's the fact -- it's the fact that he does not tell the truth about it. He first said he didn't get an induction notice
column9: then we find out that he did; he said he didn't have an ROTC slot
column10: then we find out he did; he said he didn't use Senator Fulbright's office for special influence
column11: then we find out that he did.  These are inconsistencies. Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. And he will have a very difficult time dealing with somebody like President Yeltsin or Chancellor Kohl or Prime Minister Major or President Mitterrand
column12: because truth and integrity are prerequisites to being president of the US.  (APPLAUSE)

Cold War, the definition of strong national defense has obviously changed somewhat', 'For example, George Bush wants to maintain at least 150,000 American soldiers in Europe, even though World War II ended 50 years ago', 'Bill Clinton and I agree with so many military experts who believe that it is time for the Europeans, who are so much wealthier now and more powerful than they were at the end of World War II to start picking up a little more of that tab themselves and not rely so exclusively on the US taxpayers for the defense of Europe', 'We believe that we can make savings in our defense column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column1: I believe that a woman owns her body and what she does with it is her own business

column3: abhor abortions
column4: but I don't think they should be made illegal
column5: and I don't -- and I don't think it's a political issue. I think it's a privacy issue. (APPLAUSE.)

column3: that Dan did not say I support the right of a woman to choose. That is because he and George Bush have turned over their party to Pat Buchanan and Phyllis Schlafly
column4: who have ordered them to endorse a platform which makes all abortions illegal under any circumstances
column5: regardless of what has led to that decision by a woman. Even in cases of rape and incest
column6: their platform requires that a woman be penalized
column7: that she not be allowed to make a choice
column8: if she believes
column9: in consultation with her family
column10: her doctor
column11: and others
column12: whoever she chooses
column13: that she wants to have an abortion after rape
column14: or incest. They make it completely --

column2: do you support a 24-hour waiting period?

column1: -- illegal under any of those circumstances. Now they want to waffle around --
Do you support a 24-hour waiting period?

column2: briefly. Now -- now you want to waffle around on it and give the impression that maybe you don't really mean what you say. But again
column3: you can clear it up by simply repeating I support the right of a woman to choose. Say it.

column1: Thank you. Talk about waffling around. This issue is a very important issue. It has been debated throughout your public life and throughout my public life
column2: and one thing that I don't think that it is wise to do
column3: and that is to change your position. At one time
column4: and most of the time in the House of Representatives
column5: you had a pro-life position.

column3: and we'll pass this out to the media --

column1: You wrote a letter saying that you oppose taxpayer funding of abortion. Bill Clinton has the same type of a record.
You're going to qualify it now.

column2: when he was governor of Arkansas
column3: also worked with the Right to Life people and supported Right to Life positions and now he has changed. Talk about waffling around. This is the typical type of Clinton response. Even on the issue like abortion. He's on both sides of the issue. Take the NAFTA agreement --

column1: I know you want to change the subject
column3: but let's stay on this one for a while.

column1: How long did he have to wait -- or how quickly did he change his position on education? He changes his position all the time.
Let's stay with this issue for a while.
Bill Clinton -- Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. 3 words he fears most in the English language.

column2: I want to talk about this
column3: because the question was not about free trade or education. The question --

column1: Talk about waffling. You're the one who brought up the --
-- issue of waffling. He's waffled on the abortion issue.
I let you talk. Let me talk now. It's going to be a long evening if you're like this

column3: it's not --
then.

column1: Answer my questions. On the 24 hour waiting period -- do you support that?
I have had the same position --
I have had the same position on abortion in favor of a woman's right to choose. Do you support a woman's right to choose --
Do you support a 24 hour waiting period to have --

column2: wait a minute. Let me tell you why this is so important. There are millions of women in this country who passionately believe in the right of a woman to privacy. And they want to stack the Supreme Court with justices who will take away the right to privacy. Make no mistake about it. That is their agenda -- (APPLAUSE)  And if you support them
column3: don't be surprised that that is exactly what they want to do and that is why Dan Quayle refuses to say this evening that he supports the right of a woman to choose.  I agree with Admiral Stockdale and the vast majority of Democrats and Republicans in this country. You know
column4: one of the reasons so many Republicans are supporting the Clinton- Gore ticket is because they've turned over the party to this right wing extremist group which takes positions on issues like abortion that don't even allow exceptions for rape and incest.

column2: can't you just say you support the right of a woman to choose?

column1: I would like to get in -- I feel like I'm an observer at a pingpong game
column3: you know
column4: they're expert professional politicians that massage these intricate plots and know every nuance to 'em. And meantime
column5: we're facing a desperate situation in our economy. I've seen the cost of living double in my lifetime. A new granddaughter was born in my family -- my granddaughter- -3 weeks ago. And according to the statistics that we have -- that is
column6: the Perot group -- the chances of her seeing a doubling of the standard of living are nil. In fact
column7: her children will be dead before another -- this standard of living is doubled. So what the heck! Let's get on with talking about something substantive. (APPLAUSE)

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column2: wait a minute. Let me tell you why this is so important. There are millions of women in this country who passionately believe in the right of a woman to privacy. And they want to stack the Supreme Court with justices who will take away the right to privacy. Make no mistake about it. That is their agenda -- (APPLAUSE)  And if you support them
column3: don't be surprised that that is exactly what they want to do and that is why Dan Quayle refuses to say this evening that he supports the right of a woman to choose.  I agree with Admiral Stockdale and the vast majority of Democrats and Republicans in this country. You know
column4: one of the reasons so many Republicans are supporting the Clinton- Gore ticket is because they've turned over the party to this right wing extremist group which takes positions on issues like abortion that don't even allow exceptions for rape and incest.

column1: I would like to get in -- I feel like I'm an observer at a pingpong game
column3: you know
column4: they're expert professional politicians that massage these intricate plots and know every nuance to 'em. And meantime
column5: we're facing a desperate situation in our economy. I've seen the cost of living double in my lifetime. A new granddaughter was born in my family -- my granddaughter- -3 weeks ago. And according to the statistics that we have -- that is
column6: the Perot group -- the chances of her seeing a doubling of the standard of living are nil. In fact
column7: her children will be dead before another -- this standard of living is doubled. So what the heck! Let's get on with talking about something substantive. (APPLAUSE)

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column2: wait a minute. Let me tell you why this is so important. There are millions of women in this country who passionately believe in the right of a woman to privacy. And they want to stack the Supreme Court with justices who will take away the right to privacy. Make no mistake about it. That is their agenda -- (APPLAUSE)  And if you support them
column3: don't be surprised that that is exactly what they want to do and that is why Dan Quayle refuses to say this evening that he supports the right of a woman to choose.  I agree with Admiral Stockdale and the vast majority of Democrats and Republicans in this country. You know
column4: one of the reasons so many Republicans are supporting the Clinton- Gore ticket is because they've turned over the party to this right wing extremist group which takes positions on issues like abortion that don't even allow exceptions for rape and incest.

column3: you know
column4: they're expert professional politicians that massage these intricate plots and know every nuance to 'em. And meantime
column5: we're facing a desperate situation in our economy. I've seen the cost of living double in my lifetime. A new granddaughter was born in my family -- my granddaughter- -3 weeks ago. And according to the statistics that we have -- that is
column6: the Perot group -- the chances of her seeing a doubling of the standard of living are nil. In fact
column7: her children will be dead before another -- this standard of living is doubled. So what the heck! Let's get on with talking about something substantive. (APPLAUSE)

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column2: wait a minute. Let me tell you why this is so important. There are millions of women in this country who passionately believe in the right of a woman to privacy. And they want to stack the Supreme Court with justices who will take away the right to privacy. Make no mistake about it. That is their agenda -- (APPLAUSE)  And if you support them
column3: don't be surprised that that is exactly what they want to do and that is why Dan Quayle refuses to say this evening that he supports the right of a woman to choose.  I agree with Admiral Stockdale and the vast majority of Democrats and Republicans in this country. You know
column4: one of the reasons so many Republicans are supporting the Clinton- Gore ticket is because they've turned over the party to this right wing extremist group which takes positions on issues like abortion that don't even allow exceptions for rape and incest.

column3: you know
column4: they're expert professional politicians that massage these intricate plots and know every nuance to 'em. And meantime
column5: we're facing a desperate situation in our economy. I've seen the cost of living double in my lifetime. A new granddaughter was born in my family -- my granddaughter- -3 weeks ago. And according to the statistics that we have -- that is
column6: the Perot group -- the chances of her seeing a doubling of the standard of living are nil. In fact
column7: her children will be dead before another -- this standard of living is doubled. So what the heck! Let's get on with talking about something substantive. (APPLAUSE)

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period

column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column2: wait a minute. Let me tell you why this is so important. There are millions of women in this country who passionately believe in the right of a woman to privacy. And they want to stack the Supreme Court with justices who will take away the right to privacy. Make no mistake about it. That is their agenda -- (APPLAUSE)  And if you support them
column3: don't be surprised that that is exactly what they want to do and that is why Dan Quayle refuses to say this evening that he supports the right of a woman to choose.  I agree with Admiral Stockdale and the vast majority of Democrats and Republicans in this country. You know

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period

column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.
