column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column1: I believe that a woman owns her body and what she does with it is her own business

column3: abhor abortions
column4: but I don't think they should be made illegal
column5: and I don't -- and I don't think it's a political issue. I think it's a privacy issue. (APPLAUSE.)

column3: that Dan did not say I support the right of a woman to choose. That is because he and George Bush have turned over their party to Pat Buchanan and Phyllis Schlafly
column4: who have ordered them to endorse a platform which makes all abortions illegal under any circumstances
column5: regardless of what has led to that decision by a woman. Even in cases of rape and incest
column6: their platform requires that a woman be penalized
column7: that she not be allowed to make a choice
column8: if she believes
column9: in consultation with her family
column10: her doctor
column11: and others
column12: whoever she chooses
column13: that she wants to have an abortion after rape
column14: or incest. They make it completely --

column2: do you support a 24-hour waiting period?

column1: -- illegal under any of those circumstances. Now they want to waffle around --
Do you support a 24-hour waiting period?

column2: briefly. Now -- now you want to waffle around on it and give the impression that maybe you don't really mean what you say. But again
column3: you can clear it up by simply repeating I support the right of a woman to choose. Say it.

column1: Thank you. Talk about waffling around. This issue is a very important issue. It has been debated throughout your public life and throughout my public life
column2: and one thing that I don't think that it is wise to do
column3: and that is to change your position. At one time
column4: and most of the time in the House of Representatives
column5: you had a pro-life position.

column3: and we'll pass this out to the media --

column1: You wrote a letter saying that you oppose taxpayer funding of abortion. Bill Clinton has the same type of a record.
You're going to qualify it now.

column2: when he was governor of Arkansas
column3: also worked with the Right to Life people and supported Right to Life positions and now he has changed. Talk about waffling around. This is the typical type of Clinton response. Even on the issue like abortion. He's on both sides of the issue. Take the NAFTA agreement --

column1: I know you want to change the subject
column3: but let's stay on this one for a while.

column1: How long did he have to wait -- or how quickly did he change his position on education? He changes his position all the time.

Bill Clinton -- Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth. 3 words he fears most in the English language.

I let you talk. Let me talk now. It's going to be a long evening if you're like this

column1: Answer my questions. On the 24 hour waiting period -- do you support that?
I have had the same position --
I have had the same position on abortion in favor of a woman's right to choose. Do you support a woman's right to choose --
Do you support a 24 hour waiting period to have --

column2: wait a minute. Let me tell you why this is so important. There are millions of women in this country who passionately believe in the right of a woman to privacy. And they want to stack the Supreme Court with justices who will take away the right to privacy. Make no mistake about it. That is their agenda -- (APPLAUSE)  And if you support them
column3: don't be surprised that that is exactly what they want to do and that is why Dan Quayle refuses to say this evening that he supports the right of a woman to choose.  I agree with Admiral Stockdale and the vast majority of Democrats and Republicans in this country. You know
column4: one of the reasons so many Republicans are supporting the Clinton- Gore ticket is because they've turned over the party to this right wing extremist group which takes positions on issues like abortion that don't even allow exceptions for rape and incest.

column2: can't you just say you support the right of a woman to choose?

column1: I would like to get in -- I feel like I'm an observer at a pingpong game
column3: you know
column4: they're expert professional politicians that massage these intricate plots and know every nuance to 'em. And meantime
column5: we're facing a desperate situation in our economy. I've seen the cost of living double in my lifetime. A new granddaughter was born in my family -- my granddaughter- -3 weeks ago. And according to the statistics that we have -- that is
column6: the Perot group -- the chances of her seeing a doubling of the standard of living are nil. In fact
column7: her children will be dead before another -- this standard of living is doubled. So what the heck! Let's get on with talking about something substantive. (APPLAUSE)

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column2: wait a minute. Let me tell you why this is so important. There are millions of women in this country who passionately believe in the right of a woman to privacy. And they want to stack the Supreme Court with justices who will take away the right to privacy. Make no mistake about it. That is their agenda -- (APPLAUSE)  And if you support them
column3: don't be surprised that that is exactly what they want to do and that is why Dan Quayle refuses to say this evening that he supports the right of a woman to choose.  I agree with Admiral Stockdale and the vast majority of Democrats and Republicans in this country. You know
column4: one of the reasons so many Republicans are supporting the Clinton- Gore ticket is because they've turned over the party to this right wing extremist group which takes positions on issues like abortion that don't even allow exceptions for rape and incest.

column4: they're expert professional politicians that massage these intricate plots and know every nuance to 'em. And meantime

column7: her children will be dead before another -- this standard of living is doubled. So what the heck! Let's get on with talking about something substantive. (APPLAUSE)

column3: 6)	" Bill Clinton and I support the right of a woman to choose. (APPLAUSE)  That doesn't mean we're pro-abortion; in fact
column4: we believe there are way too many abortions in this country. And the way to reduce them is by reducing the number of unwanted pregnancies
column5: not vetoing family planning legislation the way George Bush has consistently done.  The reason we are pro-choice and in favor of a woman's right to privacy is because we believe that during the early stages of a pregnancy the government has no business coming in and ordering a woman to do what the government thinks is best. What Dan Quayle and George Bush and Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson think is the right decision in a given set of circumstances is their privilege -- but don't have the government order a woman to do what they think is the right thing to do.  We ought to be able to build more common ground among those who describe themselves as pro-choice and pro-life in efforts to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies.  But
column6: Dan
column7: you can clear this up very simply by repeating after me: I support the right of a woman to choose. Can you say that?

column1: This issue is an issue that divides Americans deeply. I happen to be pro-life. I have been pro-life for my 16 years -- (APPLAUSE.)  -- in public life. My objective and the president's objective is to try to reduce abortions in this country. We have 1.6 million abortions. We have more abortions in Washington
column3: than we do live births. Why shouldn't we have more reflection upon the issue before abor -- the decision of abortion is made. I would hope that we would agree upon that. Something like a 24-hour waiting period
column4: parental notification.  I was in Los Angeles recently and I talked to a woman who told me that she had an abortion when she was 17 years of age. And looking back on that she said it was a mistake. She said -- she said I wished at that time
column5: that I was going through this difficult time
column6: that I had counseling to talk about the post-abortion trauma
column7: and talk about adoption rather than abortion. Because if I had had that discussion
column8: I would have had the child. Let's not forget that every abortion stops a beating heart. I think we have far too many abortions in this country
column9: in this country of ours.

column2: wait a minute. Let me tell you why this is so important. There are millions of women in this country who passionately believe in the right of a woman to privacy. And they want to stack the Supreme Court with justices who will take away the right to privacy. Make no mistake about it. That is their agenda -- (APPLAUSE)  And if you support them
column3: don't be surprised that that is exactly what they want to do and that is why Dan Quayle refuses to say this evening that he supports the right of a woman to choose.  I agree with Admiral Stockdale and the vast majority of Democrats and Republicans in this country. You know
column4: one of the reasons so many Republicans are supporting the Clinton- Gore ticket is because they've turned over the party to this right wing extremist group which takes positions on issues like abortion that don't even allow exceptions for rape and incest.

column1: I would like to get in -- I feel like I'm an observer at a pingpong game
column3: you know
column4: they're expert professional politicians that massage these intricate plots and know every nuance to 'em. And meantime
column5: we're facing a desperate situation in our economy. I've seen the cost of living double in my lifetime. A new granddaughter was born in my family -- my granddaughter- -3 weeks ago. And according to the statistics that we have -- that is
column6: the Perot group -- the chances of her seeing a doubling of the standard of living are nil. In fact
column7: her children will be dead before another -- this standard of living is doubled. So what the heck! Let's get on with talking about something substantive. (APPLAUSE)

column2: I think there is a case to be made for putting emphasis on character over these issues that we've been batting back and forth and have a life of their own. Sure
column3: you have to know where you're going with your government
column4: but character is the big variable in the success. Character of the leaders is the big variable in the success -- long term success -- of an administration. I went to a friend of mine in New York some years ago and he was a president of a major TV network and he said
column5: you know
column6: I think we have messed up this whole -- this election process -- it was an election year -- by stressing that -- putting out the dogma that issues are the thing to talk about
column7: not character.  He said
column8: I felt so strongly about this
column9: I went back and read the Lincoln-Douglas debates. Read those debates. How do they come down? Douglas is all character. He knows all of the little stinky numbers these guys do. Abraham Lincoln had character. Thank God we got the right president in the Civil War.  But that is a question that is a valid one
column10: and you know
column11: I would like to brag about the character of my boss.

column1: This election is about the future of our country
column2: not about personal attacks against one candidate or another. Our nation is in trouble and it is appalling to me that with 10 million Americans out work
column3: with the rest working harder for less money than they did 4 years ago
column4: with the loss of 1.4 million manufacturing jobs in our nation
column5: with the health care crisis
column6: a crisis of crime and drugs and AIDS
column7: substandard education
column8: that George Bush would constantly try to level personal attacks at his opponent. Now
column9: this
column10: of course
column11: just reached a new low last week when he resorted to a classic McCarthyite technique of trying to smear Bill Clinton over a trip that he took as a student along with lots of other Rhodes Scholars who were invited to go to Russia. It's a classic McCarthyite smear technique. I think the president of the US ought to apologize. I think that he insulted the intelligence of the American people and I'm awful proud that the American people rejected that tactic so overwhelmingly that he decided he had made a mistake. Do you think it was a mistake
column12: too
column13: Dan?

column2: you said -- and I wrote it down here -- ""personal negative attacks."" (Laughs) Has anyone been reading my press clippings for the last 4 years? (APPLAUSE)  But I happen to -- I agree with one thing on -- with Senator Gore
column3: and that is that we ought to look to the future
column4: and the future is
column5: who's going to be the next president of the US. And is it a negative attack and a personal attack to point out that Bill Clinton simply has trouble telling the truth? He said that he didn't even demonstrate -- he told the people in Arkansas in 1978. Then we find out he organized demonstrations. You know
column6: I don't care whether he demonstrated or didn't demonstrate. The fact -- the question is
column7: tell the truth. Just tell us the truth. Today
column8: Bill Clinton -- excuse me -- yesterday in Philadelphia on a radio show
column9: just yesterday on a radio show
column10: he attacked -- Admiral
column11: he attacks Ross Perot saying the media is giving Ross Perot a free ride. The press asked him when the klieg lights are on
column12: said what do you mean by Ross Perot getting a free ride? He says I didn't say that at all.  I mean
column13: you can't have it both ways. No
column14: I don't think that is a personal attack. What I find troubling with Bill Clinton is he can't tell the truth. You cannot lead this great country of ours by misleading the people.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: I think the best justification for getting Ross Perot in the race again to stay is that we're seeing this kind of chit-chat back and forth about issues that don't concentrate on where our grandchildren -- the living standards of our children and grandchildren. He is
column2: as I have read in more than one article
column3: a revolutionary; he's got plans out there that are going to double the speed at which this budget problem is being cared for. It was asked how
column4: if we would squeeze down so fast that we would strangle the economy in the process. That is an art
column5: to follow all those variables and know when to let up and to nurse this economy back together with pulls and pushes. And there's no better man in the world to do that than that old artist
column6: Ross Perot. And so I think that my closing statement is that I think I'm in a room with people that aren't the life of reality. The US is in deep trouble. We've got to have somebody that can get up there and bring out the firehoses and get it stopped
column7: and that's what we're about in the Perot campaign.

column2: our nation will make a fateful decision. We can continue traveling the road we have been on
column3: which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times
column4: or we can reach out for change. If we choose change
column5: it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction. Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they're no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction.  Bill Clinton offers a new approach. He has been named by the other 49 governors
column6: Republicans and Democrats alike
column7: as the best and most effective governor in the entire US of America.  He's moved 17
column8: 000 people off the welfare rolls and on to payrolls. He has introduced innovations in health care and education
column9: and again
column10: he has led the nation for the last 2 years in a row in the creation of jobs in the private sector.  Isn't it time for a new approach
column11: a new generation of ideas and leadership
column12: to put our nation's people first and to get our economy moving again?  We simply cannot stand to continue with this failed approach that is no good for us. Ultimately
column13: it is a choice between hope and fear
column14: a choice between the future and the past. It is time to reach out for a better nation. We are bigger than George Bush has told us we are
column15: as a nation
column16: and we have a much brighter future.  Give us a chance. With your help
column17: we'll change this country and we can't wait to get started.  (APPLAUSE.)

column2: Hal. I'd like to use this closing statement to talk to you about a few people that I have met in these last 4 years. I think of a woman in Chicago when I was talking to parents about education where she stood up and said I'm sick and tired of these schools in this city being nothing but a factory for failure. And that's why we support choice in education. I was in Beaumont
column3: Texas
column4: and met with small business people
column5: and they wanted to reform the civil justice system because they think our legal system costs too much and there's too much of a delay in getting an answer.  I was in Middletown
column6: Ohio
column7: talking to a welfare woman
column8: where she said I want to go back to work and I had a job offered to me but I'm not going to take it because I have 2 children at home and the job that is offered to me doesn't have health insurance. Under President Bush's health care reform package that woman won't have to make a choice about going back to work or health care for her children
column9: because she'll have both.  I was in Vilnius
column10: Lithuania
column11: Independence Square
column12: speaking to 10
column13: 000 people in the middle of winter. Hundreds of people came up to me and said: God bless America.  Yes
column14: in the next 4 years
column15: as I said
column16: somewhere
column17: some time
column18: there's going to be a crisis
column19: and you need to have a president that is qualified
column21: and has been tested. Not one time during this evening
column22: during 90 minutes
column23: did Al Gore tell us why Bill Clinton is qualified to be president. He never answered my charges that Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth.  The choice is yours. The American people should demand that their president tell the truth. Do you really believe -- do you really believe Bill Clinton will tell the truth? And do you
column24: do you trust Bill Clinton to be your president?  (APPLAUSE)

column1: This election is about the future of our country
column2: not about personal attacks against one candidate or another. Our nation is in trouble and it is appalling to me that with 10 million Americans out work

It's a classic McCarthyite smear technique. I think the president of the US ought to apologize. I think that he insulted the intelligence of the American people and I'm awful proud that the American people rejected that tactic so overwhelmingly that he decided he had made a mistake. Do you think it was a mistake

column1: I think the best justification for getting Ross Perot in the race again to stay is that we're seeing this kind of chit-chat back and forth about issues that don't concentrate on where our grandchildren -- the living standards of our children and grandchildren. He is
column2: as I have read in more than one article
column3: a revolutionary; he's got plans out there that are going to double the speed at which this budget problem is being cared for. It was asked how
column4: if we would squeeze down so fast that we would strangle the economy in the process. That is an art
column5: to follow all those variables and know when to let up and to nurse this economy back together with pulls and pushes. And there's no better man in the world to do that than that old artist
column6: Ross Perot. And so I think that my closing statement is that I think I'm in a room with people that aren't the life of reality. The US is in deep trouble. We've got to have somebody that can get up there and bring out the firehoses and get it stopped
column7: and that's what we're about in the Perot campaign.

column2: our nation will make a fateful decision. We can continue traveling the road we have been on
column3: which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times
column4: or we can reach out for change. If we choose change
column5: it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction. Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they're no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction.  Bill Clinton offers a new approach. He has been named by the other 49 governors
column6: Republicans and Democrats alike
column7: as the best and most effective governor in the entire US of America.  He's moved 17
column8: 000 people off the welfare rolls and on to payrolls. He has introduced innovations in health care and education
column9: and again
column10: he has led the nation for the last 2 years in a row in the creation of jobs in the private sector.  Isn't it time for a new approach
column11: a new generation of ideas and leadership
column12: to put our nation's people first and to get our economy moving again?  We simply cannot stand to continue with this failed approach that is no good for us. Ultimately
column13: it is a choice between hope and fear
column14: a choice between the future and the past. It is time to reach out for a better nation. We are bigger than George Bush has told us we are
column15: as a nation
column16: and we have a much brighter future.  Give us a chance. With your help
column17: we'll change this country and we can't wait to get started.  (APPLAUSE.)

column2: Hal. I'd like to use this closing statement to talk to you about a few people that I have met in these last 4 years. I think of a woman in Chicago when I was talking to parents about education where she stood up and said I'm sick and tired of these schools in this city being nothing but a factory for failure. And that's why we support choice in education. I was in Beaumont
column3: Texas
column4: and met with small business people
column5: and they wanted to reform the civil justice system because they think our legal system costs too much and there's too much of a delay in getting an answer.  I was in Middletown
column6: Ohio
column7: talking to a welfare woman
column8: where she said I want to go back to work and I had a job offered to me but I'm not going to take it because I have 2 children at home and the job that is offered to me doesn't have health insurance. Under President Bush's health care reform package that woman won't have to make a choice about going back to work or health care for her children
column9: because she'll have both.  I was in Vilnius
column10: Lithuania
column11: Independence Square
column12: speaking to 10
column13: 000 people in the middle of winter. Hundreds of people came up to me and said: God bless America.  Yes
column14: in the next 4 years
column15: as I said
column16: somewhere
column17: some time
column18: there's going to be a crisis
column19: and you need to have a president that is qualified
column21: and has been tested. Not one time during this evening
column22: during 90 minutes
column23: did Al Gore tell us why Bill Clinton is qualified to be president. He never answered my charges that Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth.  The choice is yours. The American people should demand that their president tell the truth. Do you really believe -- do you really believe Bill Clinton will tell the truth? And do you
column24: do you trust Bill Clinton to be your president?  (APPLAUSE)

column1: I think the best justification for getting Ross Perot in the race again to stay is that we're seeing this kind of chit-chat back and forth about issues that don't concentrate on where our grandchildren -- the living standards of our children and grandchildren. He is
column2: as I have read in more than one article
column3: a revolutionary; he's got plans out there that are going to double the speed at which this budget problem is being cared for. It was asked how
column4: if we would squeeze down so fast that we would strangle the economy in the process. That is an art
column5: to follow all those variables and know when to let up and to nurse this economy back together with pulls and pushes. And there's no better man in the world to do that than that old artist
column6: Ross Perot. And so I think that my closing statement is that I think I'm in a room with people that aren't the life of reality. The US is in deep trouble. We've got to have somebody that can get up there and bring out the firehoses and get it stopped
column7: and that's what we're about in the Perot campaign.

column2: our nation will make a fateful decision. We can continue traveling the road we have been on
column3: which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times
column4: or we can reach out for change. If we choose change
column5: it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction. Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they're no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction.  Bill Clinton offers a new approach. He has been named by the other 49 governors
column6: Republicans and Democrats alike
column7: as the best and most effective governor in the entire US of America.  He's moved 17
column8: 000 people off the welfare rolls and on to payrolls. He has introduced innovations in health care and education
column9: and again
column10: he has led the nation for the last 2 years in a row in the creation of jobs in the private sector.  Isn't it time for a new approach
column11: a new generation of ideas and leadership
column12: to put our nation's people first and to get our economy moving again?  We simply cannot stand to continue with this failed approach that is no good for us. Ultimately
column13: it is a choice between hope and fear
column14: a choice between the future and the past. It is time to reach out for a better nation. We are bigger than George Bush has told us we are
column15: as a nation
column16: and we have a much brighter future.  Give us a chance. With your help
column17: we'll change this country and we can't wait to get started.  (APPLAUSE.)

column2: Hal. I'd like to use this closing statement to talk to you about a few people that I have met in these last 4 years. I think of a woman in Chicago when I was talking to parents about education where she stood up and said I'm sick and tired of these schools in this city being nothing but a factory for failure. And that's why we support choice in education. I was in Beaumont
column3: Texas
column4: and met with small business people
column5: and they wanted to reform the civil justice system because they think our legal system costs too much and there's too much of a delay in getting an answer.  I was in Middletown
column6: Ohio
column7: talking to a welfare woman
column8: where she said I want to go back to work and I had a job offered to me but I'm not going to take it because I have 2 children at home and the job that is offered to me doesn't have health insurance. Under President Bush's health care reform package that woman won't have to make a choice about going back to work or health care for her children
column9: because she'll have both.  I was in Vilnius
column10: Lithuania
column11: Independence Square
column12: speaking to 10
column13: 000 people in the middle of winter. Hundreds of people came up to me and said: God bless America.  Yes

column15: as I said
column16: somewhere
column17: some time
column18: there's going to be a crisis
column19: and you need to have a president that is qualified
column21: and has been tested. Not one time during this evening
column22: during 90 minutes
column23: did Al Gore tell us why Bill Clinton is qualified to be president. He never answered my charges that Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth.  The choice is yours. The American people should demand that their president tell the truth. Do you really believe -- do you really believe Bill Clinton will tell the truth? And do you
column24: do you trust Bill Clinton to be your president?  (APPLAUSE)

column3: which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times
column4: or we can reach out for change. If we choose change
column5: it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction. Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they're no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction. column16: and we have a much brighter future.  Give us a chance. With your help
column17: we'll change this country and we can't wait to get started.  (APPLAUSE.)

column2: Hal. I'd like to use this closing statement to talk to you about a few people that I have met in these last 4 years. column8: where she said I want to go back to work and I had a job offered to me but I'm not going to take it because I have 2 children at home and the job that is offered to me doesn't have health insurance. column24: do you trust Bill Clinton to be your president?  (APPLAUSE)

column3: which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times
column4: or we can reach out for change. If we choose change
column5: it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction. Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they're no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction. column2: I think there is a case to be made for putting emphasis on character over these issues that we've been batting back and forth and have a life of their own. Sure
column3: you have to know where you're going with your government
column4: but character is the big variable in the success. Character of the leaders is the big variable in the success -- long term success -- of an administration. I went to a friend of mine in New York some years ago and he was a president of a major TV network and he said
column5: you know
column6: I think we have messed up this whole -- this election process -- it was an election year -- by stressing that -- putting out the dogma that issues are the thing to talk about
column7: not character.  He said
column8: I felt so strongly about this
column9: I went back and read the Lincoln-Douglas debates. Read those debates. How do they come down? Douglas is all character. He knows all of the little stinky numbers these guys do. column11: I would like to brag about the character of my boss.

column1: This election is about the future of our country
column2: not about personal attacks against one candidate or another. Our nation is in trouble and it is appalling to me that with 10 million Americans out work
column3: with the rest working harder for less money than they did 4 years ago
column4: with the loss of 1.4 million manufacturing jobs in our nation
column5: with the health care crisis
column6: a crisis of crime and drugs and AIDS
column7: substandard education
column8: that George Bush would constantly try to level personal attacks at his opponent. Now
column9: this
column10: of course
column11: just reached a new low last week when he resorted to a classic McCarthyite technique of trying to smear Bill Clinton over a trip that he took as a student along with lots of other Rhodes Scholars who were invited to go to Russia. It's a classic McCarthyite smear technique. I think the president of the US ought to apologize. I think that he insulted the intelligence of the American people and I'm awful proud that the American people rejected that tactic so overwhelmingly that he decided he had made a mistake. Do you think it was a mistake

column2: you said -- and I wrote it down here -- ""personal negative attacks."" (Laughs) Has anyone been reading my press clippings for the last 4 years? (APPLAUSE)  But I happen to -- I agree with one thing on -- with Senator Gore
column3: and that is that we ought to look to the future
column4: and the future is
column5: who's going to be the next president of the US. And is it a negative attack and a personal attack to point out that Bill Clinton simply has trouble telling the truth? He said that he didn't even demonstrate -- he told the people in Arkansas in 1978. Then we find out he organized demonstrations. You know
column6: I don't care whether he demonstrated or didn't demonstrate. The fact -- the question is
column7: tell the truth. Just tell us the truth. Today

column9: just yesterday on a radio show
column10: he attacked -- Admiral
column11: he attacks Ross Perot saying the media is giving Ross Perot a free ride. The press asked him when the klieg lights are on
column12: said what do you mean by Ross Perot getting a free ride? He says I didn't say that at all.  I mean
column13: you can't have it both ways. No
column14: I don't think that is a personal attack. What I find troubling with Bill Clinton is he can't tell the truth. You cannot lead this great country of ours by misleading the people.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: I think the best justification for getting Ross Perot in the race again to stay is that we're seeing this kind of chit-chat back and forth about issues that don't concentrate on where our grandchildren -- the living standards of our children and grandchildren. He is
column2: as I have read in more than one article
column3: a revolutionary; he's got plans out there that are going to double the speed at which this budget problem is being cared for. It was asked how
column4: if we would squeeze down so fast that we would strangle the economy in the process. That is an art
column5: to follow all those variables and know when to let up and to nurse this economy back together with pulls and pushes. And there's no better man in the world to do that than that old artist
column6: Ross Perot. And so I think that my closing statement is that I think I'm in a room with people that aren't the life of reality. The US is in deep trouble. We've got to have somebody that can get up there and bring out the firehoses and get it stopped
column7: and that's what we're about in the Perot campaign.

column2: our nation will make a fateful decision. We can continue traveling the road we have been on
column3: which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times
column4: or we can reach out for change. If we choose change
column5: it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction. Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they're no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction.  Bill Clinton offers a new approach. He has been named by the other 49 governors
column6: Republicans and Democrats alike
column7: as the best and most effective governor in the entire US of America.  He's moved 17

column12: to put our nation's people first and to get our economy moving again?  We simply cannot stand to continue with this failed approach that is no good for us. Ultimately
column13: it is a choice between hope and fear
column14: a choice between the future and the past. It is time to reach out for a better nation. We are bigger than George Bush has told us we are
column15: as a nation
column16: and we have a much brighter future.  Give us a chance. With your help
column17: we'll change this country and we can't wait to get started.  (APPLAUSE.)

column2: I think there is a case to be made for putting emphasis on character over these issues that we've been batting back and forth and have a life of their own. Sure
column3: you have to know where you're going with your government
column4: but character is the big variable in the success. Character of the leaders is the big variable in the success -- long term success -- of an administration. I went to a friend of mine in New York some years ago and he was a president of a major TV network and he said
column5: you know
column6: I think we have messed up this whole -- this election process -- it was an election year -- by stressing that -- putting out the dogma that issues are the thing to talk about
column7: not character.  He said
column8: I felt so strongly about this
column9: I went back and read the Lincoln-Douglas debates. Read those debates. How do they come down? Douglas is all character. He knows all of the little stinky numbers these guys do. Abraham Lincoln had character. Thank God we got the right president in the Civil War.  But that is a question that is a valid one
column10: and you know
column11: I would like to brag about the character of my boss.

column1: This election is about the future of our country
column2: not about personal attacks against one candidate or another. Our nation is in trouble and it is appalling to me that with 10 million Americans out work
column3: with the rest working harder for less money than they did 4 years ago
column4: with the loss of 1.4 million manufacturing jobs in our nation
column5: with the health care crisis
column6: a crisis of crime and drugs and AIDS
column7: substandard education
column8: that George Bush would constantly try to level personal attacks at his opponent. Now
column9: this
column10: of course
column11: just reached a new low last week when he resorted to a classic McCarthyite technique of trying to smear Bill Clinton over a trip that he took as a student along with lots of other Rhodes Scholars who were invited to go to Russia. It's a classic McCarthyite smear technique. I think the president of the US ought to apologize. I think that he insulted the intelligence of the American people and I'm awful proud that the American people rejected that tactic so overwhelmingly that he decided he had made a mistake. Do you think it was a mistake
column12: too
column13: Dan?

column2: you said -- and I wrote it down here -- ""personal negative attacks."" (Laughs) Has anyone been reading my press clippings for the last 4 years? (APPLAUSE)  But I happen to -- I agree with one thing on -- with Senator Gore
column3: and that is that we ought to look to the future
column4: and the future is
column5: who's going to be the next president of the US. And is it a negative attack and a personal attack to point out that Bill Clinton simply has trouble telling the truth? He said that he didn't even demonstrate -- he told the people in Arkansas in 1978. Then we find out he organized demonstrations. You know
column6: I don't care whether he demonstrated or didn't demonstrate. The fact -- the question is
column7: tell the truth. Just tell us the truth. Today
column8: Bill Clinton -- excuse me -- yesterday in Philadelphia on a radio show
column9: just yesterday on a radio show
column10: he attacked -- Admiral
column11: he attacks Ross Perot saying the media is giving Ross Perot a free ride. The press asked him when the klieg lights are on
column12: said what do you mean by Ross Perot getting a free ride? He says I didn't say that at all.  I mean
column13: you can't have it both ways. No
column14: I don't think that is a personal attack. What I find troubling with Bill Clinton is he can't tell the truth. You cannot lead this great country of ours by misleading the people.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: I think the best justification for getting Ross Perot in the race again to stay is that we're seeing this kind of chit-chat back and forth about issues that don't concentrate on where our grandchildren -- the living standards of our children and grandchildren. He is
column2: as I have read in more than one article
column3: a revolutionary; he's got plans out there that are going to double the speed at which this budget problem is being cared for. It was asked how
column4: if we would squeeze down so fast that we would strangle the economy in the process. That is an art
column5: to follow all those variables and know when to let up and to nurse this economy back together with pulls and pushes. And there's no better man in the world to do that than that old artist
column6: Ross Perot. And so I think that my closing statement is that I think I'm in a room with people that aren't the life of reality. The US is in deep trouble. We've got to have somebody that can get up there and bring out the firehoses and get it stopped
column7: and that's what we're about in the Perot campaign.

column2: our nation will make a fateful decision. We can continue traveling the road we have been on
column3: which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times
column4: or we can reach out for change. If we choose change
column5: it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction. Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they're no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction.  Bill Clinton offers a new approach. He has been named by the other 49 governors
column6: Republicans and Democrats alike
column7: as the best and most effective governor in the entire US of America.  He's moved 17
column8: 000 people off the welfare rolls and on to payrolls. He has introduced innovations in health care and education
column9: and again
column10: he has led the nation for the last 2 years in a row in the creation of jobs in the private sector.  Isn't it time for a new approach
column11: a new generation of ideas and leadership
column12: to put our nation's people first and to get our economy moving again?  We simply cannot stand to continue with this failed approach that is no good for us. Ultimately
column13: it is a choice between hope and fear
column14: a choice between the future and the past. It is time to reach out for a better nation. We are bigger than George Bush has told us we are
column15: as a nation
column16: and we have a much brighter future.  Give us a chance. With your help
column17: we'll change this country and we can't wait to get started.  (APPLAUSE.)

column2: Hal. I'd like to use this closing statement to talk to you about a few people that I have met in these last 4 years. I think of a woman in Chicago when I was talking to parents about education where she stood up and said I'm sick and tired of these schools in this city being nothing but a factory for failure. And that's why we support choice in education. I was in Beaumont
column3: Texas
column4: and met with small business people
column5: and they wanted to reform the civil justice system because they think our legal system costs too much and there's too much of a delay in getting an answer.  I was in Middletown
column6: Ohio
column7: talking to a welfare woman
column8: where she said I want to go back to work and I had a job offered to me but I'm not going to take it because I have 2 children at home and the job that is offered to me doesn't have health insurance. Under President Bush's health care reform package that woman won't have to make a choice about going back to work or health care for her children
column9: because she'll have both.  I was in Vilnius
column10: Lithuania
column11: Independence Square
column12: speaking to 10
column13: 000 people in the middle of winter. Hundreds of people came up to me and said: God bless America.  Yes
column14: in the next 4 years
column15: as I said
column16: somewhere
column17: some time
column18: there's going to be a crisis
column19: and you need to have a president that is qualified
column21: and has been tested. Not one time during this evening
column22: during 90 minutes
column23: did Al Gore tell us why Bill Clinton is qualified to be president. He never answered my charges that Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth.  The choice is yours. The American people should demand that their president tell the truth. Do you really believe -- do you really believe Bill Clinton will tell the truth? And do you
column24: do you trust Bill Clinton to be your president?  (APPLAUSE)

column2: you said -- and I wrote it down here -- ""personal negative attacks."" (Laughs) Has anyone been reading my press clippings for the last 4 years? (APPLAUSE)  But I happen to -- I agree with one thing on -- with Senator Gore
column3: and that is that we ought to look to the future
column4: and the future is
column5: who's going to be the next president of the US. And is it a negative attack and a personal attack to point out that Bill Clinton simply has trouble telling the truth? He said that he didn't even demonstrate -- he told the people in Arkansas in 1978. Then we find out he organized demonstrations. You know
column6: I don't care whether he demonstrated or didn't demonstrate. The fact -- the question is
column7: tell the truth. Just tell us the truth. Today
column8: Bill Clinton -- excuse me -- yesterday in Philadelphia on a radio show
column9: just yesterday on a radio show
column10: he attacked -- Admiral
column11: he attacks Ross Perot saying the media is giving Ross Perot a free ride. The press asked him when the klieg lights are on
column12: said what do you mean by Ross Perot getting a free ride? He says I didn't say that at all.  I mean
column13: you can't have it both ways. No
column14: I don't think that is a personal attack. What I find troubling with Bill Clinton is he can't tell the truth. You cannot lead this great country of ours by misleading the people.  (APPLAUSE)

column1: I think the best justification for getting Ross Perot in the race again to stay is that we're seeing this kind of chit-chat back and forth about issues that don't concentrate on where our grandchildren -- the living standards of our children and grandchildren. He is
column2: as I have read in more than one article
column3: a revolutionary; he's got plans out there that are going to double the speed at which this budget problem is being cared for. It was asked how
column4: if we would squeeze down so fast that we would strangle the economy in the process. That is an art
column5: to follow all those variables and know when to let up and to nurse this economy back together with pulls and pushes. And there's no better man in the world to do that than that old artist
column6: Ross Perot. And so I think that my closing statement is that I think I'm in a room with people that aren't the life of reality. The US is in deep trouble. We've got to have somebody that can get up there and bring out the firehoses and get it stopped
column7: and that's what we're about in the Perot campaign.

column2: our nation will make a fateful decision. We can continue traveling the road we have been on
column3: which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times
column4: or we can reach out for change. If we choose change
column5: it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction. Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they're no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction.  Bill Clinton offers a new approach. He has been named by the other 49 governors
column6: Republicans and Democrats alike
column7: as the best and most effective governor in the entire US of America.  He's moved 17
column8: 000 people off the welfare rolls and on to payrolls. He has introduced innovations in health care and education
column9: and again
column10: he has led the nation for the last 2 years in a row in the creation of jobs in the private sector.  Isn't it time for a new approach
column11: a new generation of ideas and leadership
column12: to put our nation's people first and to get our economy moving again?  We simply cannot stand to continue with this failed approach that is no good for us. Ultimately
column13: it is a choice between hope and fear
column14: a choice between the future and the past. It is time to reach out for a better nation. We are bigger than George Bush has told us we are
column15: as a nation
column16: and we have a much brighter future.  Give us a chance. With your help
column17: we'll change this country and we can't wait to get started.  (APPLAUSE.)

column2: Hal. I'd like to use this closing statement to talk to you about a few people that I have met in these last 4 years. I think of a woman in Chicago when I was talking to parents about education where she stood up and said I'm sick and tired of these schools in this city being nothing but a factory for failure. And that's why we support choice in education. I was in Beaumont
column3: Texas
column4: and met with small business people
column5: and they wanted to reform the civil justice system because they think our legal system costs too much and there's too much of a delay in getting an answer.  I was in Middletown
column6: Ohio
column7: talking to a welfare woman
column8: where she said I want to go back to work and I had a job offered to me but I'm not going to take it because I have 2 children at home and the job that is offered to me doesn't have health insurance. Under President Bush's health care reform package that woman won't have to make a choice about going back to work or health care for her children
column9: because she'll have both.  I was in Vilnius
column10: Lithuania
column11: Independence Square
column12: speaking to 10
column13: 000 people in the middle of winter. Hundreds of people came up to me and said: God bless America.  Yes
column14: in the next 4 years
column15: as I said
column16: somewhere
column17: some time
column18: there's going to be a crisis
column19: and you need to have a president that is qualified
column21: and has been tested. Not one time during this evening
column22: during 90 minutes
column23: did Al Gore tell us why Bill Clinton is qualified to be president. He never answered my charges that Bill Clinton has trouble telling the truth.  The choice is yours. The American people should demand that their president tell the truth. Do you really believe -- do you really believe Bill Clinton will tell the truth? And do you
column24: do you trust Bill Clinton to be your president?  (APPLAUSE)

column6: Ross Perot. And so I think that my closing statement is that I think I'm in a room with people that aren't the life of reality. The US is in deep trouble. We've got to have somebody that can get up there and bring out the firehoses and get it stopped
column7: and that's what we're about in the Perot campaign.

column2: our nation will make a fateful decision. We can continue traveling the road we have been on
column3: which has led to higher unemployment and worse economic times
column4: or we can reach out for change. If we choose change
column5: it will require us to reach down inside ourselves to find the courage to take a new direction. Sometimes it seems deceptively easy to continue with the old habits even when they're no longer good for us. Trickle-down economics simply does not work. We have had an increase in all of the things that should be decreasing. Everything that should have been increasing has been going down. We have got to change direction.  Bill Clinton offers a new approach. He has been named by the other 49 governors
column6: Republicans and Democrats alike
column7: as the best and most effective governor in the entire US of America.  He's moved 17
column8: 000 people off the welfare rolls and on to payrolls. He has introduced innovations in health care and education
column9: and again
column10: he has led the nation for the last 2 years in a row in the creation of jobs in the private sector.  Isn't it time for a new approach
column11: a new generation of ideas and leadership
column12: to put our nation's people first and to get our economy moving again?  We simply cannot stand to continue with this failed approach that is no good for us. Ultimately
column13: it is a choice between hope and fear
column14: a choice between the future and the past. It is time to reach out for a better nation. We are bigger than George Bush has told us we are
column15: as a nation
column16: and we have a much brighter future.  Give us a chance. With your help
column17: we'll change this country and we can't wait to get started.  (APPLAUSE.)

column2: Hal. I'd like to use this closing statement to talk to you about a few people that I have met in these last 4 years. And that's why we support choice in education. I was in Beaumont
column3: Texas

column8: where she said I want to go back to work and I had a job offered to me but I'm not going to take it because I have 2 children at home and the job that is offered to me doesn't have health insurance. column2: Hal. I'd like to use this closing statement to talk to you about a few people that I have met in these last 4 years. I think of a woman in Chicago when I was talking to parents about education where she stood up and said I'm sick and tired of these schools in this city being nothing but a factory for failure. And that's why we support choice in education. I was in Beaumont
